pull_request.title: Fix for alg_support.cmake
pull_request.body:
Addresses the following cases:

- If I compile with `-DOQS_ALGS_ENABLED=STD`, I still expect the aarch64 (or avx2) variants available by default if they are supported on the target machine.
- If I compile with `-DOQS_ALGS_ENABLED=STD`, ~~I expect both ml-dsa-44-ipd and its alias ml-dsa-44 to be available, although only the alias was specified in the "STD" list.~~ ml-dsa-44 is added to the STD list but not ml-dsa-44-ipd

It's addressed by refactoring alg_support.cmake and the fragments that generate it, by moving the cmake statements to conditionally activate platform-specific code and aliases below the calls to "filter_algs". filter_algs would otherwise remove these dependencies.

Adds a test to CI to check if both a ml-dsa-ipd and a ml-dsa alias is available with the STD build.

Adds missing bike_l5 to the NIST_R4 algs list (unless this variant wasn't there intentionally).

Fixes #1703 
Fixes #1704

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -109,6 +109,8 @@ These default choices have been made in order to optimize the default performanc
 
 When `OQS_USE_OPENSSL` is `ON`, CMake also scans the filesystem to find the minimum version of OpenSSL required by liboqs (which happens to be 1.1.1). The [OPENSSL_ROOT_DIR](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/module/FindOpenSSL.html) option can be set to aid CMake in its search.
 
+By default, when `OQS_USE_OPENSSL` is `ON`, OpenSSL will be linked to liboqs at build time. This is sometimes undesirable when using liboqs from other cryptographic libraries. The separate option `OQS_DLOPEN_OPENSSL` can be used to defer loading OpenSSL at run time if it is `ON`. The default for this option is `OFF`.
comment.body: This is somewhat confusing (e.g., which option is by default OFF and ON?). What speaks against giving this new option it's own heading (maybe a tad deeper than OQS_USE_OPENSSL, i.e., prefixed with "###")? This also would allow directly referencing it as it'll get its own anchor. Also missing is a statement along the lines "Only available on platforms supporting `dlopen`, e.g., not on Windows" (or so).

pull_request.title: Add option to dynamically load libcrypto.so.*
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

As discussed on #1599, this is a strawman proposal to make the common cryptographic algorithms (AES, SHA2, SHA3, and RNG) switchable to avoid OpenSSL dependency at package installation time. The applications can replace the implementation by providing custom callback functions for with `OQS_AES_set_callbacks`, `OQS_SHA2_set_callbacks`,
`OQS_SHA3_set_callbacks`, and `OQS_SHA3_x4_callbacks`.

This also adds `OQS_DLOPEN_OPENSSL` build option to use OpenSSL through dynamically loaded libcrypto.so.* with dlopen, instead of linking to the library at build time.

@@ -40,7 +40,11 @@ The OQS project is supported by the [Post-Quantum Cryptography Alliance](https:/
 
 Details on each supported algorithm can be found in the [docs/algorithms](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/tree/main/docs/algorithms) folder.
 
-The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those algorithms have been selected for standardization by NIST, specifically Kyber (excluding the "-90s" variants), Dilithium (excluding the "-AES" variants), Falcon, and SPHINCS+ (excluding the "robust" variants). Activating only those standardized algorithms for use in `liboqs` can be facilitated by setting the [OQS_ALGS_ENABLED](CONFIGURE.md#oqs_algs_enabled) build configuration variable to `STD`. By default `liboqs` is built supporting all, incl. experimental, PQ algorithms listed below.
+The list below indicates all algorithms currently supported by liboqs, including experimental algorithms and already excluding algorithm variants pruned during the NIST competition, such as Kyber-90s or Dilithium-AES.
+
+The currently only algorithms selected for standardization are the "ML-KEM" and "ML-DSA" variants with their respective different bit strengths. `liboqs` will retain these algorithm names selected by NIST throughout the finishing stages of the standardization process, so users can rely on their presence going forward. If NIST changes the implementation details of these algorithms, `liboqs` will adapt the implementation such as for users to not be impacted by such potential change. For users interested in explicitly selecting the current "proposed draft standard" code, the variants with the suffix "-ipd" are made available. At this stage, "ml-kem-ipd" and "ml-kem" as well as "ml-dsa-ipd" and "ml-dsa" are functionally equivalent, denoted by the "alias" moniker below.

comment.body:
Falcon and SPHINCS+ have both been selected for standardization, but those names will change. For Falcon, there is no FIPS draft yet. For SPHINCS+, [there is](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/205/ipd), but we don't yet have an implementation of "SLH-DSA" (and indeed I'm not sure what tweaks the draft makes to the Round 3 version of SPHINCS+).

I think it makes sense to reword this to state something like
```
The only algorithms in `liboqs` that implement NIST standards drafts are the "ML-KEM" and "ML-DSA" variants...
```
and additionally add a sentence saying
```
Falcon and SPHINCS+ have also been selected for standardization, but the `liboqs` implementations of these algorithms are currently tracking Round 3 submissions and not NIST standards drafts.
```
I think this conveys the commitment to keep the ML-KEM and ML-DSA names (and currently only those names) stable throughout the standardization process, while recognizing that Falcon and SPHINCS+ are also soon to be standardized. Whenever we have implementations of SLH-DSA and NTRU-DSA (or whatever other name NIST settles on for Falcon) we can add them to this list of stables names too.

Sorry, I should have caught this on my first pass.

A full resolution may entail introducing a new algorithm class "STD-track" [as discussed elsewhere](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1716#issuecomment-1976252544) (leaving only "ML-KEM" and "ML-DSA" in the STD designation). But IMO this warrants some more deliberation and should not stop 0.10.0.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,7 +40,11 @@ The OQS project is supported by the [Post-Quantum Cryptography Alliance](https:/
 
 Details on each supported algorithm can be found in the [docs/algorithms](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/tree/main/docs/algorithms) folder.
 
-The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those algorithms have been selected for standardization by NIST, specifically Kyber (excluding the "-90s" variants), Dilithium (excluding the "-AES" variants), Falcon, and SPHINCS+ (excluding the "robust" variants). Activating only those standardized algorithms for use in `liboqs` can be facilitated by setting the [OQS_ALGS_ENABLED](CONFIGURE.md#oqs_algs_enabled) build configuration variable to `STD`. By default `liboqs` is built supporting all, incl. experimental, PQ algorithms listed below.
+The list below indicates all algorithms currently supported by liboqs, including experimental algorithms and already excluding algorithm variants pruned during the NIST competition, such as Kyber-90s or Dilithium-AES.
+
+The only algorithms currently selected for standardization are the "ML-KEM", "ML-DSA", "Falcon" and "Sphincs+" variants with their respective different bit strengths. `liboqs` will retain these algorithm names selected by NIST throughout the finishing stages of the standardization process, so users can rely on their presence going forward. If NIST changes the implementation details of these algorithms, `liboqs` will adapt the implementation such as for users to not be impacted by such potential change. For users interested in explicitly selecting the current "proposed draft standard" code, the variants with the suffix "-ipd" are made available. At this stage, "ml-kem-ipd" and "ml-kem" as well as "ml-dsa-ipd" and "ml-dsa" are functionally equivalent, denoted by the "alias" moniker below.
comment.body:
```suggestion
The only algorithms in `liboqs` that implement NIST standards drafts are the [`ML-KEM`](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/203/ipd) and [`ML-DSA`](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/204/ipd) variants with their respective different bit strengths. `liboqs` will retain these algorithm names selected by NIST throughout the finishing stages of the standardization process, so users can rely on their presence going forward. If NIST changes the implementation details of these algorithms, `liboqs` will adapt the implementation such as for users to not be impacted by such potential change. For users interested in explicitly selecting the current "proposed draft standard" code, the variants with the suffix "-ipd" are made available. At this stage, "ml-kem-ipd" and "ml-kem" as well as "ml-dsa-ipd" and "ml-dsa" are functionally equivalent, denoted by the "alias" moniker below.

Falcon and SPHINCS+ have also been [selected for standardization](https://csrc.nist.gov/Projects/post-quantum-cryptography/selected-algorithms-2022), but the `liboqs` implementations of these algorithms are currently tracking Round 3 submissions and not NIST standards drafts.
```

Adding as a suggestion to avoid potentially introducing a conflict on @baentsch's branch.

Activating only those standardized algorithms for use in `liboqs` can be facilitated by setting the [OQS_ALGS_ENABLED](CONFIGURE.md#oqs_algs_enabled) build configuration variable to `STD`. +The list below indicates all algorithms currently supported by liboqs, including experimental algorithms and already excluding algorithm variants pruned during the NIST competition, such as Kyber-90s or Dilithium-AES.
+
+The only algorithms in `liboqs` that implement NIST standards drafts are the [`ML-KEM`](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/203/ipd) and [`ML-DSA`](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/204/ipd) variants with their respective different bit strengths. `liboqs` will retain these algorithm names selected by NIST throughout the finishing stages of the standardization process, so users can rely on their presence going forward. If NIST changes the implementation details of these algorithms, `liboqs` will adapt the implementation such as for users to not be impacted by such potential change. For users interested in explicitly selecting the current "proposed draft standard" code, the variants with the suffix "-ipd" are made available. +

+
+All other algorithm names are subject to change. `liboqs` makes available a [selection mechanism for algorithms on the NIST standards track, continued NIST competition, or purely experimental nature by way of the configuration variable OQS_ALGS_ENABLED](CONFIGURE.md#oqs_algs_enabled). By default `liboqs` is built supporting all, incl. experimental, PQ algorithms listed below.

pull_request.title: Implementation of Composite Sig
pull_request.body:
This is an implementation of the version 10 [Composite Signatures For Use In Internet PKI](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ounsworth-pq-composite-sigs/).
Current status of this work:
- I'm working on fixing the issues pointed by the Git Actions workflow tests.
- There will be alterations to update this for version 11 when it is released.
- To be precise with the IETF draft, we need to wait for ML-DSA-ipd to be implemented.

comment.body:
I'm supposing you are speaking about the OPENSSL_cleanse.
I cannot free buf at that point because buf is used inside p8inf_internal, so if I free it when I free p8inf_internal I would get a double free error.
So I'm cleansing it to remove the pkey data from memory and on the next line I'm doing [PKCS8_PRIV_KEY_INFO_free](https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man3/PKCS8_PRIV_KEY_INFO_free.html) to free the p8inf_internal which include the buf.

comment.body:
I accept it because at first glance it seems fine, but then I went to test it and remembered why I did that.
Some cases of the RSA keys the size of the key will not match the size on oqsxkey->privkeylen_cmp, this value represent the maximum size for the RSA, so I cant copy oqsxkey->privkeylen_cmp because it will cause overflow in some cases.
